user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetFsInfo:
```c
int32 OS_GetFsInfo(os_fsinfo_t *filesys_info)
{
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filesys_info);

    memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info));

    filesys_info->MaxFds     = OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES;
    filesys_info->MaxVolumes = OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS;

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeFds;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeVolumes;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetFsInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
typedef struct
{
    uint32 MaxFds;      /**< @brief Total number of file descriptors */
    uint32 FreeFds;     /**< @brief Total number that are free */
    uint32 MaxVolumes;  /**< @brief Maximum number of volumes */
    uint32 FreeVolumes; /**< @brief Total number of volumes free */
} os_fsinfo_t
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
#define OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES 50
...
#define OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS 14
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS 0x0B
...
bool OS_FileSysFilterFree(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    return !OS_ObjectIdDefined(obj->active_id);
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t matchfunc, void *matcharg, osal_objtype_t objtype,
                              OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    iter->match = matchfunc;
    iter->arg   = matcharg;
    iter->limit = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(objtype);
    iter->base  = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(objtype)];

    return OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, objtype, &iter->token);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the code in the provided snippets does not present obvious unreachable-code concerns and therefore does not need investigation for MISRA C Rule 2.1: - The simple parameter check expansion (other than the macro call itself) is ordinary and either allows normal flow or aborts early; the subsequent memset and assignments (filesys_info->MaxFds/MaxVolumes) are straightforward initializations and reachable when the function continues. - The OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit and OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy calls are initializer/cleanup helpers; they are reachable from the function flow and do not contain unreachable branches in the shown code. - The two calls to OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit use different object-type constants; those initializations and the subsequent returns/cleanup are standard control flow. - The assignments and the final return (return OS_SUCCESS;) are reachable as the function completes. - Small utility functions shown (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit, OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel) contain only setup/teardown and a single return; nothing in the provided definitions indicates unreachable statements beyond the fragments already listed. Therefore investigation should focus on the listed fragments which contain conditional loops, macro-based checks, and formatting/IO branches that could hide unreachable code or rely on macros/initial states that make parts of the code never execute.
